title: 113_s1308
content:
The Act titled "Energy Savings Through Public-Private Partnerships Act of 2013" is cited as the short title. The findings section follows. The Energy Savings Through Public-Private Partnerships Act of 2013 acknowledges the benefits of private sector funding in addressing energy efficiency challenges in the US. It highlights the potential for reducing Federal energy costs through performance contracts and utility energy service contracts, which can upgrade facilities without upfront taxpayer costs. Performance contracting aims to retrofit Federal buildings, improve infrastructure, and cut operational expenses. SEC. 3. USE OF ENERGY EFFICIENCY MEASURES IN FEDERAL BUILDINGS. Implementation of Identified Energy Efficiency Measures:
Energy managers must consider implementing energy-saving measures identified in evaluations within 2 years. This includes bundling cost-effective measures into combined projects. Energy managers must provide reasons for not implementing cost-effective measures and track annual contracting goals for Federal agencies. Each Federal agency must track energy savings from implemented measures and submit the information to the Department of Energy for publication on a public website. Agencies should consider using performance contracts or utility energy service contracts for energy-saving initiatives. The Federal Government aims to enter into energy savings performance contracts or utility energy service contracts totaling $1 billion annually for a 5-year period starting in 2014. Each Federal agency must report their energy savings annually to the Secretary of Energy. The Federal Government agencies must report their progress towards achieving the $1 billion annual energy savings goal to the Secretary of Energy. The Secretary will then submit a report to the relevant congressional committees every September 30th.
